articles.headline: Amazon in Big Push for New Kindle Model
articles.snippet: Though the upgrades to the electronic book reader were only incremental, Amazon defined some ambitious goals for the device.
articles.abstract: Though the upgrades to the electronic book reader were only incremental, Amazon defined some ambitious goals for the device.
articles.lead_paragraph: Setting up an obvious battle with Google and another possible one with Apple in the fast-growing electronic-book business, Amazon.com on Monday introduced the Kindle 2, a new version of its popular e-book reader.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: F.D.A. Finds ‘Natural’ Diet Pills Laced With Drugs
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration says the weight-loss capsules StarCaps contain a potent pharmaceutical drug called bumetanide, which can have serious side effects.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration says the weight-loss capsules StarCaps contain a potent pharmaceutical drug called bumetanide, which can have serious side effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Grady Jackson, a defensive tackle with the Atlanta Falcons, said he used the weight-loss capsules. Kathie Lee Gifford was enthusiastic about them on the “Today” show. Retailers like GNC and the Vitamin Shoppe sold them, no prescription required.

articles.headline: Top Enforcer at the S.E.C. Steps Down
articles.snippet: Linda Chatman Thomsen was front and center at a House hearing last week investigating the Madoff scandal and the enforcement breakdown at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.abstract: Linda Chatman Thomsen was front and center at a House hearing last week investigating the Madoff scandal and the enforcement breakdown at the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: Signaling that it is time for a new cop to walk the Wall Street beat, the Securities and Exchange Commission accepted the resignation Monday of its top enforcement officer amid blistering criticism that the commission had failed to protect investors in recent years.

articles.headline: After Iraqi Elections, Next Big Test Is Acceptance
articles.snippet: Iraq’s elections passed with strikingly little mayhem, but the results have riled those vying for power.
articles.abstract: Iraq’s elections passed with strikingly little mayhem, but the results have riled those vying for power.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMADI, Iraq  The postelection curfew has been lifted, the threats of violence muted after the intervention of envoys from the Iraqi Army, the central government and the United States Marines. A cacophonous bustle has returned to the filthy, shattered streets of this provincial capital, once a base of the Sunni insurgency.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Sam Dagher

articles.headline: Calls for Clarity in New Bailout for U.S. Banks
articles.snippet: As the Obama administration prepares to lay out plans for a revamped bank bailout, the initial instinct to shield banks from public scrutiny has created new problems.
articles.abstract: As the Obama administration prepares to lay out plans for a revamped bank bailout, the initial instinct to shield banks from public scrutiny has created new problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Congress passed the $700 billion bank bailout last October, the Bush administration confronted a thorny question: Should it require banks to account for how they spend taxpayer money?
articles.byline: By David Barstow and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Geithner Said to Have Prevailed on the Bailout
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary opposed tougher conditions on financial institutions that were sought by presidential aides.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary opposed tougher conditions on financial institutions that were sought by presidential aides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON The Obama administration’s new plan to bail out the nation’s banks was fashioned after a spirited internal debate that pitted the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, against some of the president’s top political hands.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Losses Mount on Credit Cards for Retailers
articles.snippet: Outstanding balances from retail credit cards are outpacing losses in the general market.
articles.abstract: Outstanding balances from retail credit cards are outpacing losses in the general market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Though only a small corner of the credit card market, cards that can be used only at a single retailer are quickly turning into a big headache for their issuers.

articles.headline: Months After Plant Closed, Many Still Struggling
articles.snippet: Workers from a tool factory in Ohio have struggled to find jobs since the plant closed 10 months ago.
articles.abstract: Workers from a tool factory in Ohio have struggled to find jobs since the plant closed 10 months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW FRANKLIN, Ohio  It has been 10 months since most of the workers walked out of the plain, low-slung factory here for the final time. The building, which had been home to the Manchester Tool Company since just after World War II, sits dormant now, a “for sale or lease” sign in front, buried recently in a fresh snowfall.

articles.headline: Obama Makes Case as Bill Clears Hurdle
articles.snippet: President Obama used his presidential platform to address concerns about his economic recovery plan.
articles.abstract: President Obama used his presidential platform to address concerns about his economic recovery plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama took his case for his $800 billion economic recovery package to the American people on Monday, as the Senate cleared the way for passage of the bill and the White House prepared for its next major hurdle: selling Congress and the public on a fresh plan to bail out the nation’s banks.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Up Next for Bankers: A Flogging
articles.snippet: Ten questions members of the House Financial Services Committee might consider asking the bank executives making their way to Washington.
articles.abstract: Ten questions members of the House Financial Services Committee might consider asking the bank executives making their way to Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, eight chief executives of big banks will make their way to Washington  giving up their private jets and instead riding Amtrak and the Delta Shuttle  to appear at a Congressional hearing in front of Representative Barney Frank and the House Financial Services Committee.

articles.headline: Battle Is Close in Israeli Election
articles.snippet: The close race all but guaranteed that political jockeying to assemble a governing coalition would be intense.
articles.abstract: The close race all but guaranteed that political jockeying to assemble a governing coalition would be intense.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Israel’s centrist Kadima Party led by Foreign Minister Tzipi Livni and the more conservative Likud Party led by Benjamin Netanyahu were locked in a tight battle for leadership early Wednesday that left unclear the shape of the next Israeli government.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: Stocks Slide as New Bailout Disappoints
articles.snippet: Investors expected Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner to unveil a shock-and-awe solution, but the new plan raised more questions than it answered.
articles.abstract: Investors expected Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner to unveil a shock-and-awe solution, but the new plan raised more questions than it answered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors had been expecting the Obama administration to unveil a shock and awe solution on Tuesday for the nation’s hobbled banking system. But the main reaction was disappointment as the new plan raised more questions than it answered, sending stock markets and the shares of banks assumed to be holding toxic assets sharply lower.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Bailout Plan: $2.5 Trillion and a Strong U.S. Hand
articles.snippet: The White House plan to rescue the financial system is far bigger than predicted and envisions a far greater government role in markets and banks than at any time since the 1930s.
articles.abstract: The White House plan to rescue the financial system is far bigger than predicted and envisions a far greater government role in markets and banks than at any time since the 1930s.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House plan to rescue the nation’s financial system, announced on Tuesday by Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, is far bigger than anyone predicted and envisions a far greater government role in markets and banks than at any time since the 1930s.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Stephen Labaton
